title: 6 pC particle set - electric potential at 1 cm

content.description: A particle with a charge of <math alttext="positive 6 picocoulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn></mpadded><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>pC</mi></math> moves along the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math>-axis due to the presence of an electric field. The particle is released from rest at <math alttext="x equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Assume that gravitational forces are negligible.
content.question: From observing the particleâ€™s motion, it is determined that the electric potential energy of the particle-field system has decreased by <math alttext="3 picojoules" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>pJ</mi></math> when the particle is located at <math alttext="x equals 1.0 centimeter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1.0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math>. What is the electric potential at <math alttext="x equals 1.0 centimeter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1.0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math> relative to the electric potential at <math alttext="x equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> ?

skill.text: 2.A: Derive a symbolic expression from known quantities by selecting and following a logical mathematical pathway.
